As regards the curse by the Brahmana boy, Pariksit as the emperor of the world, he was
ruling from his capital city, Hastinapura. He once went hunting, because the Kshatriyas
had to practice killing to keep themselves fit for giving protection to the citizens.
So he went hunting and he became thirsty. He started searching for water. He came across
the ashram of one Shamika Rishi. He went inside that ashram and he saw that there was a
sage sitting there, half-closed eyes. The sage was in meditation. So the sage was not
conscious of his externals. But Pariksit, being very thirsty, not finding water, not
being welcomed by this sage, he mistook the sage to be feigning to be meditating in order
to avoid receiving the king. So Pariksit became angry. He took one dead snake that was just
lying outside the ashram of that Shamika Rishi, garlanded the sage who was sitting in meditation
room with that dead snake and walked away from that place. As he was going away, Pariksit
reflected on what he did. Then he began to consider, maybe the sage was actually in trance.
He was not externally conscious. So how could he have received me properly? How could he
have even noticed me entering his ashram? And why did I insult the sage in that way?
He doesn't deserve to be insulted in that way at all. So reflecting on his action, Pariksit began to feel very, very repentant for having
